statements.name: PROC SIMILARITY
statements.description: The SIMILARITY procedure computes similarity measures associated with time-stamped data, time series, and/or other sequentially ordered numeric data. The procedure computes similarity measures for time- stamped transactional data (transactions) with respect to time by accumulating the data into a time series format (time series). The procedure computes similarity measures for sequentially ordered numeric data (sequences) by respecting the ordering of the data. † Given two ordered numeric sequences (input and target), a similarity measure is a metric that measures the distance between the input and target sequences while taking into account the ordering of the data. The SIMILARITY procedure computes similarity measures between an input sequence and a target sequence, as well as similarity measures that "slide" the target sequence with respect to the input sequence. The "slides" can be by observation index (sliding-sequence similarity measures) or by seasonal index (seasonal- sliding-sequence similarity measures).

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that contains the time series, transactional, or sequence input data for the procedure. If the DATA= option is not specified, the most recently created SAS data set is used.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the order that the variables listed in the INPUT and TARGET statements are processed. This ordering affects the OUTSEQUENCE=, OUTPATH=, OUTMEASURE=, and OUTSUM= data sets, as well as the printed and graphical output.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the time series variables specified in the subsequent INPUT and TARGET statements. If an ID variable is specified, it is also included in the OUT= data set.

arguments.name: OUTMEASURE=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the detailed similarity measures by time ID value. The form of the OUTMEASURE= data set is determined by the PROC SIMILARITY statement SORTNAMES and ORDER= options.

arguments.name: OUTPATH=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the path used to compute the similarity measures for each slide and warp. The form of the OUTPATH= data set is determined by the PROC SIMILARITY statement SORTNAMES and ORDER= options.

arguments.name: OUTSEQUENCE=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the sequences used to compute the similarity measures for each slide and warp. The form of the OUTSEQUENCE= data set is determined by the PROC SIMILARITY statement SORTNAMES and ORDER= options.

arguments.name: OUTSUM=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the similarity measure summary. The OUTSUM= data set is particularly useful when analyzing large numbers of series and only the summary of the results are needed. The form of the OUTSUM= data set is determined by the PROC SIMILARITY statement SORTNAMES and ORDER= options.

arguments.name: INPUT
arguments.description: Specifies that each INPUT variable is processed and then the TARGET variables are processed. The results are stored and printed based only on the INPUT variables.

arguments.name: INPUTTARGET
arguments.description: Specifies that each INPUT variable is processed and then the TARGET variables are processed. The results are stored and printed based on both the INPUT and TARGET variables. This is the default.

arguments.name: TARGET
arguments.description: Specifies that each TARGET variable is processed and then the INPUT variables are processed. The results are stored and printed based only on the TARGET variables.

arguments.name: TARGETINPUT
arguments.description: Specifies that each TARGET variable is processed and then the INPUT variables are processed. The results are stored and printed based on both the TARGET and INPUT variables.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the graphical output desired. The options are separated by spaces. By default, the SIMILARITY procedure produces no graphical output.
arguments.help: PLOTS=ALL | COSTS | DISTANCES | INPUTS | MAPS | MEASURES | NORMALIZED | PATHS | SCALED | SEQUENCES | TARGETS | WARPS

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Same as PLOTS=(INPUTS TARGETS SEQUENCES NORMALIZED SCALED DISTANCES PATHS MAPS WARPS COST MEASURES).

arguments.name: COSTS
arguments.description: Plots time warp costs graphics.

arguments.name: DISTANCES
arguments.description: Plots similarity absolute and relative distances graphics. (OUTPATH= data set)

arguments.name: INPUTS
arguments.description: Plots input variable time series graphics. (OUT= data set)

arguments.name: MAPS
arguments.description: Plots time warp maps graphics. (OUTPATH= data set)

arguments.name: MEASURES
arguments.description: Plots similarity measure graphics. (OUTMEASURE= data set)

arguments.name: NORMALIZED
arguments.description: Plots both the input and target variable normalized sequence graphics. These plots are displayed only when the INPUT or TARGET statement NORMALIZE= option is specified.

arguments.name: PATHS
arguments.description: Plots time warp paths graphics. (OUTPATH= data set)

arguments.name: SCALED
arguments.description: Plots both the input variable scaled sequence graphics. These plots are displayed only when the INPUT statement SCALE= option is specified.

arguments.name: SEQUENCES
arguments.description: Plots both the input and target variable sequence graphics. (OUTSEQUENCE= data set)

arguments.name: TARGETS
arguments.description: Plots target variable time series graphics. (OUT= data set)

arguments.name: WARPS
arguments.description: Plots time warps graphics. (OUTPATH= data set)

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Specifies the printed output desired. The options are separated by spaces. By default, the SIMILARITY procedure produces no printed output.
arguments.help: PRINT=DESCSTATS | PATHS | COSTS | WARPS | SLIDES | SUMMARY | ALL

arguments.name: DESCSTATS
arguments.description: Prints the descriptive statistics for the working time series.

arguments.name: PATHS
arguments.description: Prints the path statistics table.

arguments.name: COSTS
arguments.description: Prints the cost statistics table.

arguments.name: WARPS
arguments.description: Prints the warp summary table.

arguments.name: SLIDES
arguments.description: Prints the slides summary table.

arguments.name: SUMMARY
arguments.description: Prints the similarity measure summary table.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Same as PRINT=(DESCSTATS PATHS COSTS WARPS SLIDES SUMMARY)

arguments.name: PRINTDETAILS
arguments.description: Specifies that output requested with the PRINT= option be printed in greater detail.

arguments.name: SEASONALITY=
arguments.description: Specifies the length of the seasonal cycle where integer ranges from one to 10,000. For example, SEASONALITY=3 means that every group of three time periods forms a seasonal cycle. By default, the length of the seasonal cycle is one (no seasonality) or the length implied by the INTERVAL= option specified in the ID statement. For example, INTERVAL=MONTH implies that the length of the seasonal cycle is twelve.

arguments.name: SORTNAMES
arguments.description: Specifies that the variables specified in the INPUT and TARGET statements are processed in order sorted by the variable names. By default, the SIMILARITY procedure processes the variables in the order they are listed. The ORDER= option also affects the ordering of the analysis.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: A BY statement can be used with PROC SIMILARITY to obtain separate dummy variable definitions for groups of observations defined by the BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: FCMPOPT
statements.description: The FCMPOPT statement specifies the options related to user-defined functions and subroutines.

arguments.name: QUIET=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the nonfatal errors and warnings generated by the user-defined SAS language functions and subroutines are printed to the log. Nonfatal errors are usually associated with operations with missing values.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Nonfatal errors and warnings generated by the user-defined SAS language functions and subroutines are printed to the log. This is the default.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Nonfatal errors and warnings generated by the user-defined SAS language functions and subroutines are not printed to the log.

arguments.name: TRACE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the user-defined SAS language functions and subroutines tracings are printed to the log. Tracings are the results of every operation executed. This option is generally used for debugging. The default is TRACE=OFF.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: User-defined SAS language functions and subroutines tracings are printed to the log.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: User-defined SAS language functions and subroutines tracings are not printed to the log. This is the default.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement names a numeric variable that identifies observations in the input and output data sets. The ID variable’s values are assumed to be SAS date, time, or datetime values. In addition, the ID statement specifies the (desired) frequency associated with the time series. The ID statement options also specify how the observations are accumulated and how the time ID values are aligned to form the time series. The options specified affect all variables listed in subsequent INPUT and TARGET statements. If an ID statement is specified, the INTERVAL= option must also be specified. The other ID statement options are optional. If an ID statement is not specified, the observation number, with respect to the BY group, is used as the time ID.

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period. The frequency (width of each time interval) is specified by the INTERVAL= option.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATE=NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE|AVG | MINIMUM|MIN | MEDIAN|MED | MAXIMUM|MAX | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV|STD | CSS | USS

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No accumulation occurs; the ID variable values must be equally spaced with respect to the frequency. This is the default option.

arguments.name: TOTAL
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the total sum of their values.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the average of their values.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the minimum of their values.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the median of their values.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the maximum of their values.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of nonmissing observations.

arguments.name: NMISS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of missing observations.

arguments.name: NOBS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of observations.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the first of their values.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the last of their values.

arguments.name: STDDEV
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the standard deviation of their values.

arguments.name: CSS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the corrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: USS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the uncorrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: ALIGN=
arguments.description: Controls the alignment of SAS dates used to identify output observations.

arguments.name: BEGINNING
arguments.description: SAS dates aligned in the BEGINNING.

arguments.name: MIDDLE
arguments.description: SAS dates aligned in the MIDDLE.

arguments.name: ENDING
arguments.description: SAS dates aligned in the ENDING.

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS date or datetime literal value that represents the end of the data.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS format for the time ID values. If the FORMAT= option is not specified, the default format is implied from the INTERVAL= option.

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the frequency of the input time series or for the time series to be accumulated from the input data.
arguments.help: INTERVAL=DAY | HOUR | MINUTE | SECOND | WEEK | MONTH | YEAR | QTR | TENDAY | SEMIMONTH | SEMIYEAR

arguments.name: DAY
arguments.description: DAY interval

arguments.name: HOUR
arguments.description: HOUR interval

arguments.name: MINUTE
arguments.description: MINUTE interval

arguments.name: SECOND
arguments.description: SECOND interval

arguments.name: WEEK
arguments.description: WEEK interval

arguments.name: MONTH
arguments.description: MONTH interval

arguments.name: YEAR
arguments.description: YEAR interval

arguments.name: QTR
arguments.description: QTR interval

arguments.name: TENDAY
arguments.description: TENDAY interval

arguments.name: SEMIMONTH
arguments.description: SEMIMONTH interval

arguments.name: SEMIYEAR
arguments.description: SEMIYEAR interval

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that the time ID values are not in sorted order. The ESM procedure sorts the data with respect to the time ID prior to analysis.

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either input or accumulated) are assigned in the accumulated time series. If a number n is specified (SETMISSING=n), missing values are set to that number.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Missing values are set to missing. This is the default option.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated average value.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated minimum value.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated median value.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated maximum value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated first nonmissing value.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated last nonmissing value.

arguments.name: PREVIOUS
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the previous accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the beginning of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: NEXT
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the next accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the end of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS date or datetime literal value that represents the beginning of the data. If the first time ID variable value is greater than the START= value, the series is prepended with missing values. If the first time ID variable value is less than the START= value, the series is truncated. The START= and END= options can be used to ensure that data associated with each BY group contains the same number of observations.

arguments.name: ZEROMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how beginning and/or ending zero values (either input or accumulated) are interpreted in the accumulated time series.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Beginning and/or ending zeros are unchanged. This is the default.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Beginning zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Ending zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending zeros are set to missing.

statements.name: INPUT
statements.description: The INPUT statement lists the input numeric variables in the DATA= data set whose values are to be accumulated to form the time series or represent ordered numeric sequences (when no ID statement is specified).

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period for the variables listed in the INPUT statement.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATE=NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV | CSS | USS

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No accumulation occurs; the ID variable values must be equally spaced with respect to the frequency. This is the default option.

arguments.name: TOTAL
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the total sum of their values.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the average of their values.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the minimum of their values.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the median of their values.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the maximum of their values.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of nonmissing observations.

arguments.name: NMISS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of missing observations.

arguments.name: NOBS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of observations.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the first of their values.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the last of their values.

arguments.name: STDDEV
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the standard deviation of their values.

arguments.name: CSS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the corrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: USS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the uncorrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: DIF=
arguments.description: Specifies the differencing to be applied to the accumulated time series. The list of differencing orders must be separated by spaces or commas. For example, DIF=(1,3) specifies first, then third order, differencing. Differencing is applied after time series transformation. The TRANSFORM= option is applied before the DIF= option. Simple differencing is useful when you want to detrend the time series before computing the similarity measures.

arguments.name: NORMALIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the sequence normalization to be applied to the working input sequence.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No normalization is applied. This option is the default.

arguments.name: ABSOLUTE
arguments.description: Absolute normalization is applied.

arguments.name: STANDARD
arguments.description: Standard normalization is applied.

arguments.name: [USER-DEFINED]
arguments.description: Normalization is computed by a user-defined subroutine created using the FCMP procedure, where [USER-DEFINED] is the subroutine name.

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: Specifies the scaling of the working input sequence with respect to the working target sequence. Scaling is performed after normalization.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No scaling is applied. This option is the default.

arguments.name: ABSOLUTE
arguments.description: Absolute scaling is applied.

arguments.name: STANDARD
arguments.description: Standard scaling is applied.

arguments.name: [USER-DEFINED]
arguments.description: Scaling is computed by a user-defined subroutine created using the FCMP procedure, where [USER-DEFINED] is the subroutine name.

arguments.name: SDIF=
arguments.description: Specifies the seasonal differencing to be applied to the accumulated time series. The list of seasonal differencing orders must be separated by spaces or commas. For example, SDIF=(1,3) specifies first, then third, order seasonal differencing. Differencing is applied after time series transformation. The TRANSFORM= option is applied before the SDIF= option. Seasonal differencing is useful when you want to deseasonalize the time series before computing the similarity measures.

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are interpreted in the accumulated time series or ordered sequence for variables listed in the INPUT statement.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Missing values are set to missing. This is the default option.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated average value.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated minimum value.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated median value.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated maximum value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated first nonmissing value.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated last nonmissing value.

arguments.name: PREVIOUS
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the previous accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the beginning of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: NEXT
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the next accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the end of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: TRANSFORM=
arguments.description: Specifies the time series transformation to be applied to the accumulated time series.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No transformation is applied. This option is the default.

arguments.name: LOG
arguments.description: Logarithmic transformation is applied.

arguments.name: SQRT
arguments.description: Square-root transformation is applied.

arguments.name: LOGISTIC
arguments.description: Logistic transformation is applied.

arguments.name: BOXCOX
arguments.description: Box-Cox transformation with parameter is applied, where the real number is between -5 and 5.

arguments.name: [USER-DEFINED]
arguments.description: Transformation is computed by a user-defined subroutine created using the FCMP procedure where [USER-DEFINED] is the subroutine name.

arguments.name: TRIMMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are trimmed from the accumulated time series or ordered sequence for variables listed in the INPUT statement.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No missing value trimming is applied.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Beginning missing values are trimmed.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Ending missing values are trimmed.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending missing value are trimmed. This is the default.

arguments.name: ZEROMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how beginning and/or ending zero values (either actual or accumulated) are interpreted in the accumulated time series or ordered sequence for variables listed in the INPUT statement.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Beginning and/or ending zeros are unchanged. This is the default.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Beginning zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Ending zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending zeros are set to missing.

statements.name: TARGET
statements.description: The TARGET statement lists the numeric target variables in the DATA= data set whose values are to be accumulated to form the time series or represent ordered numeric sequences (when no ID statement is specified). An input data set variable can be specified in only one INPUT or TARGET statement. Any number of TARGET statements can be used.

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period for the variables listed in the TARGET statement.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATE=NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV | CSS | USS

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No accumulation occurs; the ID variable values must be equally spaced with respect to the frequency. This is the default option.

arguments.name: TOTAL
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the total sum of their values.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the average of their values.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the minimum of their values.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the median of their values.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the maximum of their values.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of nonmissing observations.

arguments.name: NMISS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of missing observations.

arguments.name: NOBS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of observations.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the first of their values.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the last of their values.

arguments.name: STDDEV
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the standard deviation of their values.

arguments.name: CSS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the corrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: USS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the uncorrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: COMPRESS=
arguments.description: Specifies the sliding sequence (global) and warping (local) compression range of the target sequence with respect to the input sequence. Compression of the target sequence is the same as expansion of the input sequence and vice versa. The compression limits are defined based on the length of the target sequence and are imposed on the target sequence.

arguments.name: GLOBALABS=
arguments.description: Specifies the absolute global compression, where integer ranges from zero to 10,000. GLOBALABS=0 implies no global compression, which is the default unless the GLOBALPCT= option is specified.

arguments.name: GLOBALPCT=
arguments.description: Specifies global compression as a percentage of the length of the target sequence, where number ranges from zero to 100. GLOBALPCT=0 implies no global compression, which is the default. GLOBALPCT=100 implies maximum allowable compression.

arguments.name: LOCALABS
arguments.description: Specifies the absolute local compression, where integer ranges from zero to 10,000. The default is maximum allowable absolute local compression unless the LOCALPCT= option is specified.

arguments.name: LOCALPCT=
arguments.description: Specifies local compression as a percentage of the length of the input sequence, where number ranges from zero to 100. The percentage specified by the LOCALPCT= option must be less than the GLOBALPCT= option. LOCALPCT=0 implies no local compression. LOCALPCT=100 implies maximum allowable local compression. The default is LOCALPCT=100.

arguments.name: DIF=
arguments.description: Specifies the differencing to be applied to the accumulated time series. The list of differencing orders must be separated by spaces or commas. For example, DIF=(1,3) specifies first, then third order, differencing. Differencing is applied after time series transformation. The TRANSFORM= option is applied before the DIF= option. Simple differencing is useful when you want to detrend the time series before computing the similarity measures.

arguments.name: EXPAND=
arguments.description: Specifies the sliding sequence (global) and warping (local) expansion range of the target sequence with respect to the input sequence. Expansion of the target sequence is the same as compression of the input sequence and vice versa. The expansion limits are defined based on the length of the input sequence, but are imposed on the target sequence.

arguments.name: GLOBALABS=
arguments.description: Specifies the absolute global expansion, where integer ranges from zero to 10,000. GLOBALABS=0 implies no global expansion, which is the default unless the GLOBALPCT= option is specified.

arguments.name: GLOBALPCT=
arguments.description: Specifies global expansion as a percentage of the length of the target sequence, where number ranges from zero to 100. GLOBALPCT=0 implies no global expansion, which is the default. GLOBALPCT=100 implies maximum allowable expansion.

arguments.name: LOCALABS
arguments.description: Specifies the absolute local expansion, where integer ranges from zero to 10,000. The default is maximum allowable absolute local expansion unless the LOCALPCT= option is specified.

arguments.name: LOCALPCT=
arguments.description: Specifies local expansion as a percentage of the length of the input sequence, where number ranges from zero to 100. The percentage specified by the LOCALPCT= option must be less than the GLOBALPCT= option. LOCALPCT=0 implies no local expansion. LOCALPCT=100 implies maximum allowable local expansion. The default is LOCALPCT=100.

arguments.name: MEASURE=
arguments.description: Specifies the similarity measure to be computed by using the working input and target sequences.
arguments.help: MEASURE=SQRDEV | ABSDEV | MSQRDEV | MSQRDEVINP | MSQRDEVTAR | MSQRDEVMIN | MSQRDEVMAX | MABSDEV | MABSDEVINP | MABSDEVTAR | MABSDEVMIN | MABSDEVMAX | [USER-DEFINED]

arguments.name: SQRDEV
arguments.description: Squared deviation. This option is the default.

arguments.name: ABSDEV
arguments.description: Absolute deviation

arguments.name: MSQRDEV
arguments.description: Mean squared deviation

arguments.name: MSQRDEVINP
arguments.description: Mean squared deviation relative to the length of the input sequence

arguments.name: MSQRDEVTAR
arguments.description: Mean squared deviation relative to the length of the target sequence

arguments.name: MSQRDEVMIN
arguments.description: Mean squared deviation relative to the minimum valid path length

arguments.name: MSQRDEVMAX
arguments.description: Mean squared deviation relative to the maximum valid path length

arguments.name: MABSDEV
arguments.description: Mean absolute deviation

arguments.name: MABSDEVINP
arguments.description: Mean absolute deviation relative to the length of the input sequence

arguments.name: MABSDEVTAR
arguments.description: Mean absolute deviation relative to the length of the target sequence

arguments.name: MABSDEVMIN
arguments.description: Mean absolute deviation relative to the minimum valid path length

arguments.name: MABSDEVMAX
arguments.description: Mean absolute deviation relative to the maximum valid path length

arguments.name: [USER-DEFINED]
arguments.description: Measure computed by a user-defined function created by using the FCMP procedure, where [USER-DEFINED] is the function name.

arguments.name: NORMALIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the sequence normalization to be applied to the working target sequence.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No normalization is applied. This option is the default.

arguments.name: ABSOLUTE
arguments.description: Absolute normalization is applied.

arguments.name: STANDARD
arguments.description: Standard normalization is applied.

arguments.name: [USER-DEFINED]
arguments.description: Normalization is computed by a user-defined subroutine created using the FCMP procedure, where [USER-DEFINED] is the subroutine name.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: Specifies the similarity measure and warping path information to be computed using the working input and target sequences. The following similarity measures and warping path are provided:

arguments.name: SDIF=
arguments.description: Specifies the seasonal differencing to be applied to the accumulated time series. The list of seasonal differencing orders must be separated by spaces or commas. For example, SDIF=(1,3) specifies first, then third, order seasonal differencing. Differencing is applied after time series transformation. The TRANSFORM= option is applied before the SDIF= option. Seasonal differencing is useful when you want to deseasonalize the time series before computing the similarity measures.

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are interpreted in the accumulated time series or ordered sequence for variables listed in the TARGET statement.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Missing values are set to missing. This is the default option.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated average value.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated minimum value.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated median value.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated maximum value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated first nonmissing value.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated last nonmissing value.

arguments.name: PREVIOUS
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the previous accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the beginning of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: NEXT
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the next accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the end of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: SLIDE=
arguments.description: Specifies the sliding of the target sequence with respect to the input sequence.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No sequence sliding. The input time series is compared with the target sequence directly with no sliding. This option is the default.

arguments.name: INDEX
arguments.description: Slide by time index. The input time series is compared with the target sequence by observation index.

arguments.name: SEASON
arguments.description: Slide by seasonal index. The input time series is compared with the target sequence by seasonal index.

arguments.name: TRANSFORM=
arguments.description: Specifies the time series transformation to be applied to the accumulated time series.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No transformation is applied. This option is the default.

arguments.name: LOG
arguments.description: Logarithmic transformation is applied.

arguments.name: SQRT
arguments.description: Square-root transformation is applied.

arguments.name: LOGISTIC
arguments.description: Logistic transformation is applied.

arguments.name: BOXCOX
arguments.description: Box-Cox transformation with parameter is applied, where the real number is between -5 and 5.

arguments.name: [USER-DEFINED]
arguments.description: Transformation is computed by a user-defined subroutine created using the FCMP procedure where [USER-DEFINED] is the subroutine name.

arguments.name: TRIMMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are trimmed from the accumulated time series or ordered sequence for variables listed in the TARGET statement.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No missing value trimming is applied.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Beginning missing values are trimmed.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Ending missing values are trimmed.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending missing value are trimmed. This is the default.

arguments.name: ZEROMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how beginning and/or ending zero values (either actual or accumulated) are interpreted in the accumulated time series or ordered sequence for variables listed in the TARGET statement.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Beginning and/or ending zeros are unchanged. This is the default.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Beginning zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Ending zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending zeros are set to missing.
